thread.title: ROCCityChick Recommends: Oct 8 - 11

author: democratandchronicle.com
title: ROCCityChick Recommends: Oct 8 - 11
text:
No plans? Check out ROCCityChick's top five exhilarating, quirky and occasionally off-the-beaten-path events happening right here at home. THURSDAY
Film fun: ImageOut, Rochester's very own annual LGBT Film Festival, will be celebrating its 23rd run on Thursday. The festival, which features over 70 full-length films and shorts from 21 countries, will play through Sunday, Oct. 18. Films will be shown at various theatres, including the Little Theatre and Dryden. Visit ImageOut.org for a full film and theater schedule or call 585-271-2640 with questions. Ticket prices range from $5 to $220.
Moonlight madness: Always a hit with both adults and children, Long Acre Farms has brought back its Moonlight Maze! An ideal semi-spooky challenge that will get kids revved up for Halloween, the maze opens at 6 p.m. and closes at 11 p.m. (hopefully you will have found your way out by then!) Tickets are $11 per person and the last entry tickets to the maze are sold at 9 p.m. Visit Longacrefarms.com to learn more.
SATURDAY
Furry festivities: Kick off fall and enjoy an evening of fun for the whole family filled with all of the creatures who call Beaver Meadow home. The Enchanted Forest event is a evening celebration with the animals (played by interpreters in costume), and includes storytelling, crafts, games, snacks and more. Taking place both Saturday and Sunday from 6 to 9 p.m. at the Buffalo Audubon Society, 1610 Welch Road, North Java, pre-registration is required. Call 585-457-3228 or Buffaloaudubon.org to learn more. Cost is $8 per person, free to ages 3 and younger.
Art in the park: Calling all art-lovers! Pack all of your friends and family in the car and head out to Letchworth State Park for the 40th anniversary of its Arts and Crafts Show & Sale . Guests can explore over 300 vendors, live entertainment, more food than you can possibly eat and a variety of activities. Admission to the art show and parking is free, as long as you pay the $8 per car fee to enter the park. In addition, curbside pickup of heavy purchases and handicap parking will be made available. Letchworth State Park is located at 1 Letchworth State Park, Castile. Visit the Arts Council for Wyoming County to learn more about the art show: Artswyco.org
SUNDAY
Step up and support: Another event the whole family will love, and the proceeds go to a great cause! Come out and support the Child Advocacy Center of the Finger Lakes and victims of child abuse via the 3rd Annual Step Up for Kids 5K Trail Run/Walk and Family Fun Run. The race will be held on the scenic trails of the Finger Lakes Community College campus in Canandaigua, 3325 Marvin Sands Drive. The event will include activities for the kids, awards, cash prizes, custom race shirts, post-race refreshments and more. Race-day registration begins at 7:45 a.m., the 5K starts at 9 a.m. and the family run will commence at 10 a.m. Costs for the race range between $12 and $30. Visit cacfingerlakes.org to learn more.
This Columbus Day, join the Garden Factory for their Pirate and Princesses Breakfast, benefitting the Pirate Toy Fund. (Photo: Courtesy of Garden Factory)
MONDAY
Ahoy, Matey!: This Columbus Day, adorn your child in his or her best pirate or princess outfit and head over to The Garden Factory's 3rd Annual Pirates and Princesses Breakfast, a tasty and fun event that benefits the Pirate Toy Fund. The morning's breakfast, held from 9 - 10:30 a.m., will be hosted by Jim's Too and will include pancakes, sausage, juice and more. After breakfast, guests can make cool crafts, get a pirate tattoo, take a picture in front of a pirate ship, and receive free admission to the Factory's Halloween light show, which starts at 10:30 a.m. The Garden Factory is located at 2126 Buffalo Road and tickets range from $6 to $10. Visit Gardenfactoryny.com for more information.
ROCCityChick has arrived to share exhilarating, quirky and occasionally off-the-beaten-path events happening right here at home. From fashion events and concerts, to exhibitions, protests and peculiar gatherings, she never misses a beat. A Rochester transplant by way of South Florida, ROCCityChick, the alter ego of Where the People Are reporter Marisa Zeppieri-Caruana, has returned to her home state to cover the city's can't-miss events. Known for her offbeat yet thoughtful reporting, she enjoys covering the unconventional aspects of life and thrives on the energy of an enthusiastic and passionate crowd. In her free time, she is a self-proclaimed zombie aficionada and coffee connoisseur who loves to spook the neighbors with her appalling Just Dance moves. Whether you are jonesing for a concert, rooting for a cause, or craving an exhibition, follow her weekly recommendations so you can plan your fun accordingly.
Aware of a noteworthy event? Email her at Mzeppieri@gannett.com or chat via Twitter: @ROCCityChick .
